lg.l: Hurrah for the Flax, the evergreen Flax; Evergreen Flax. Harakeke, or phormium tenax, is an evergreen perennial.
With its fibres tough and strong, Fibres tough and strong. Maori had long utilised harakeke/flax fibre, or muka, and European scientists ascertained early in the 1800s that it was stronger than hemp.
That forms the ropes Ropes. One of the main uses of fibre produced in settler flax mills was rope manufacture. of the ships that float,
And urges the seamen’s song.
Hurrah for the Flax, the evergreen Flax,
That binds the neat thatch’d cot,
That makes the mat, that secures the stack
From the rain and tempest shock.
Hurrah for the Flax, the evergreen Flax,
With its soft and honey'd spear; Honey’d spear. Harakeke/flax produces long flower spikes, and its flowers are rich in nectar.
How the children laugh as its sweets they quaff,
And home in triumph bear.
Hurrah for the Flax, the evergreen Flax,
As it stands in bright array,
Like an arm’d host, each at his post,
Impatient for the fray.
Hurrah for the Flax, the evergreen Flax,
When the wintry storms prevail,
When the ox may look for a shelter’d nook
From the bitter breathing gale.
Hurrah for the Flax, the evergreen Flax,
That falls before the adze,
While its root remains how the strength it strains
Of the ploughman Ploughman. The swamps where flax/harakeke grows were often drained by settlers to create farmland. and his nags.
Hurrah for the Flax, the evergreen Flax,
That hill and plain Hill and plain. Different species of flax/harakeke grow in lowland swamp and mountain environments. adorn;
‘Tis an emblem of strength, till it falls at length
To give place to the waving Corn.

body.p: Kaikorai. Kaikorai. The Kaikorai valley is near the centre of Dunedin, in the south of the South Island. Flax/harakeke grew widely in pre-colonial Dunedin.
